messages.name: UpstreamSpec
messages.description: Configuration for Static Upstreams

fields.name: hosts
fields.description:
A list of addresses and ports
at least one must be specified
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: enable_ipv6
fields.description: Enable ipv6 addresses to be used for routing

fields.name: tls
fields.description: Attempt to use outbound TLS

messages.name: Host
messages.description: Represents a single instance of an upstream

fields.name: addr
fields.description: Address (hostname or IP)

fields.name: port
fields.description: Port the instance is listening on

messages.name: RouteExtensions
messages.description:
RouteExtensions should be placed in the route.extensions field
RouteExtensions extend the behavior of a regular route in gloo (within a virtual service)

fields.name: add_request_headers
fields.description: These headers will be added to the request before it is sent to the upstream
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: add_response_headers
fields.description: These headers will be added to the response before it is returned to the downstream
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: remove_response_headers
fields.description: These headers will be removed from the request before it is sent to the upstream
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: max_retries
fields.description: The maximum number of retries to attempt for requests that get a 5xx response

fields.name: timeout
fields.description: If set, time out requests on this route. If not set, this will default to the connection timeout on the upstream

fields.name: host_rewrite
fields.description: Rewrite the host header of the request to this value, if set

fields.name: cors
fields.description: Configure Cross-Origin Resource Sharing requests

messages.name: HeaderValue
messages.description: Header name/value pair

fields.name: key
fields.description: Header name

fields.name: value
fields.description: Header value

fields.name: append
fields.description: Should this value be appended?

messages.name: CorsPolicy
messages.description: Configuration for Cross-Origin Resource Sharing requests

fields.name: allow_origin
fields.description:
Specifies the origins that will be allowed to do CORS requests.

An origin is allowed if either allow_origin matches.
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: allow_methods
fields.description: Specifies the content for the *access-control-allow-methods* header.

fields.name: allow_headers
fields.description: Specifies the content for the *access-control-allow-headers* header.

fields.name: expose_headers
fields.description: Specifies the content for the *access-control-expose-headers* header.

fields.name: max_age
fields.description: Specifies the content for the *access-control-max-age* header.

fields.name: allow_credentials
fields.description: Specifies whether the resource allows credentials.

messages.name: ListenerConfig
messages.description: the listenerConfig must be either an InboundListener or an OutboundListener

messages.name: InboundListenerConfig
messages.description:
configuration for the inbound listener
this listener does authentication and connects
clients to the local service

fields.name: auth_config
fields.description: configuration for tls-based auth filter

fields.name: local_service_address
fields.description:
the address of the local upstream being proxied
the service being proxied must be reachable by Envoy

fields.name: local_service_name
fields.description: the name of the local consul service being proxied

messages.name: AuthConfig
messages.description:
AuthConfig contains information necessary to
communicate with the Authentication Server (Consul Agent)

fields.name: target
fields.description:
The name of the service who owns this proxy
Target must be delivered by the filter as part of the authorize request payload

fields.name: authorize_hostname
fields.description: the hostname of the authorization REST service

fields.name: authorize_port
fields.description: the port of the authorization REST service

fields.name: authorize_path
fields.description:
the request path for the authorization REST service
NOTE: currently ignored by the plugin and filter

fields.name: request_timeout
fields.description:
Connection Timeout tells the filter to set a timeout for unresponsive connections created to this upstream.
If not provided by the user, it will set to a default value

messages.name: OutboundListenerConfig
messages.description: The configuration for the outbound listeners which serve as "tcp routes"

fields.name: destination_consul_service
fields.description: The name of the consul service which is the destination for the listener

fields.name: destination_consul_type
fields.description: TODO (ilackarms): support destination type in Consul Connect API

messages.name: FunctionSpec
messages.description: Function Spec for Functions on Azure Functions Upstreams

fields.name: function_name
fields.description: The Name of the Azure Function as it appears in the Azure Functions Portal

fields.name: auth_level
fields.description:
Auth Level can bve either "anonymous" "function" or "admin"
See https://vincentlauzon.com/2017/12/04/azure-functions-http-authorization-levels/ for more details

messages.name: UpstreamSpec
messages.description: Upstream Spec for Azure Functions Upstreams

fields.name: function_app_name
fields.description: The Name of the Azure Function App where the functions are grouped

fields.name: secret_ref

messages.name: FunctionSpec
messages.description: Function Spec for Functions on AWS Lambda Upstreams

fields.name: function_name
fields.description: The Name of the Lambda Function as it appears in the AWS Lambda Portal

fields.name: qualifier
fields.description:
The Qualifier for the Lambda Function. Qualifiers act as a kind of version
for Lambda Functions. See https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/API_Invoke.html for more info.

messages.name: UpstreamSpec
messages.description: Upstream Spec for AWS Lambda Upstreams

fields.name: region
fields.description: The AWS Region in which to run Lambda Functions

fields.name: secret_ref
fields.description:
A [Gloo Secret Ref](https://gloo.solo.io/introduction/concepts/#Secrets) to an AWS Secret
AWS Secrets can be created with `glooctl secret create aws ...`
If the secret is created manually, it must conform to the following structure:
 ```
 access_key: <aws access key>
 secret_key: <aws secret key>
 ```

messages.name: NatsStreaming
messages.description: [#proto-status: experimental]

messages.name: Attribute
messages.description:
An attribute is a container for configuration that is intended to be applied across a set of labeled resources inside of Gloo.
Attributes specify a set of selectors which are compared with labels by Gloo at runtime
In the current implementation, only Listeners have be selected, and therefore configured by Attributes.
Labels and Selectors follow the same logical patterns implemented by Kubernetes.
Read about the Kubernetes concepts here: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/overview/working-with-objects/labels/
Attributes are useful when applying shared configuration to a large number of objects, such as the sharing of route
configuration between roles.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the attribute.

Attribute Names must be unique and follow the following syntax rules:
One or more lowercase rfc1035/rfc1123 labels separated by '.' with a maximum length of 253 characters.

fields.name: status
fields.description:
Status indicates the validation status of the attribute resource.
Status is read-only by clients, and set by gloo during validation

fields.name: metadata
fields.description: Metadata contains the resource metadata for the attribute

messages.name: ListenerAttribute
messages.description:
Listeners define the address:port where the proxy will listen for incoming connections
Each listener defines a unique set of TCP and HTTP behaviors

fields.name: selector
fields.description:
Apply this attribute to listeners with label keys and values matching this
selector. If empty or not present, the attribute will not be applied to any listeners.
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: virtual_services
fields.description:
Listeners can serve HTTP or raw TCP, but not both. If at least one Virtual Service is specified here,
the listener will become an HTTP listener serving routes defined in these virtual services.
Some Listener plugins may impose restrictions on the Virtual Services that can be applied to a listener.
For example, some plugins may require all applied virtual services only route to a specific upstream,
a common requirement for Service Meshes
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: config
fields.description:
Config contains top-level config to be applied to a listener
Listener config is applied to all TCP/HTTP traffic that
initiates via this listener.
Configuration such as gzip compression and TLS authentication is specified here
This config struct will be merged with Role-specific Listener Conig. If two fields overlap between the
Listener config on the role and the config on the attribute, the config on the Role will supersede this one

messages.name: Config
messages.description: Config is a top-level config object. It is used internally by gloo as a container for the entire set of config objects.

fields.name: upstreams
fields.description: The list of all upstreams defined by the user.
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: virtual_services
fields.description: the list of all virtual services defined by the user.
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: roles
fields.description: the list roles defined by the user
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: attributes
fields.description: the list attributes defined by the user
fields.label: repeated

messages.name: Metadata
messages.description: Metadata contains general properties of config resources useful to clients and the gloo control plane for purposes of versioning, annotating, and namespacing resources.

fields.name: resource_version
fields.description: ResourceVersion keeps track of the resource version of a config resource. This mechanism is used by [gloo-storage](https://github.com/solo-io/gloo/pkg/storage) to ensure safety with concurrent writes/updates to a resource in storage.

fields.name: namespace
fields.description: Namespace is used for the namespacing of resources. Currently unused by gloo internally.

fields.name: annotations
fields.description: Annotations allow clients to tag resources for special use cases. gloo ignores annotations but preserved them on read/write from/to storage.
fields.label: repeated

messages.name: Role
messages.description:
A Role is a container for a set of Virtual Services that will be used to generate a single proxy config
to be applied to one or more Envoy nodes. The Role is best understood as an in-mesh application's localized view
of the rest of the mesh.
Each domain for each Virtual Service contained in a Role cannot appear more than once, or the Role
will be invalid.
Roles contain a config field which can be written to for the purpose of applying configuration and policy
to groupings of Virtual Services.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the role. Envoy nodes will be assigned a config matching the role they report to Gloo when registering
Envoy instances must specify their role in the prefix for their Node ID when they register to Gloo.

Currently this is done in the format <Role>~<this portion is ignored>
which can be specified with the `--service-node` flag, or in the Envoy instance's bootstrap config.

Role Names must be unique and follow the following syntax rules:
One or more lowercase rfc1035/rfc1123 labels separated by '.' with a maximum length of 253 characters.

fields.name: listeners
fields.description:
define each listener the proxy will create
listeners define a set of behaviors for a single address:port
where the proxy will listen
if no listeners are specified, the role will behave as a gateway
see (pkg/api/defaults/v1)[https://github.com/solo-io/gloo/tree/master/pkg/api/defaults/v1]
to see the default listeners that will be created for Gateway proxies
binding to the default HTTP (8080) and HTTPS (8443) ports on 0.0.0.0 (all interfaces)
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: status
fields.description:
Status indicates the validation status of the role resource.
Status is read-only by clients, and set by gloo during validation

fields.name: metadata
fields.description: Metadata contains the resource metadata for the role

messages.name: Listener
messages.description:
Listeners define the address:port where the proxy will listen for incoming connections
Each listener defines a unique set of TCP and HTTP behaviors

fields.name: name
fields.description: the name of the listener. names must be unique for listeners within a role

fields.name: bind_address
fields.description:
the bind address for the listener.
both ipv4 and ipv6 formats are supported

fields.name: bind_port
fields.description:
the port to bind on
ports numbers must be unique for listeners within a role

fields.name: virtual_services
fields.description:
defines the set of virtual services that will be accessible by clients connecting to this listener.
at least one virtual service must be specifiedfor HTTP-level features to be applied at the listener level
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: config
fields.description:
Config contains top-level config to be applied to a listener
Listener config is applied to all TCP/HTTP traffic that
initiates via this listener.
Configuration such as gzip compression and TLS authentication is specified here

fields.name: labels
fields.description:
Apply Listener Attributes to listeners with selectors matching these label keys and values
If empty or not present, the Listener will inherit no configuration from Attributes.
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: ssl_config
fields.description:
SSL Config is optional for the role. If provided, the listener will serve TLS for connections on this port
this is useful when there are no virtual services assigned to this listener, e.g. for the purpose of
securing a Listener functioning as a TCP Proxy
if no virtual services are defined and ssl_config is nil, the proxy will serve tcp connections insecurely on this port

values.name: Pending
values.description: Pending status indicates the resource has not yet been validated

values.name: Accepted
values.description: Accepted indicates the resource has been validated

values.name: Rejected
values.description:
Rejected indicates an invalid configuration by the user
Rejected resources may be propagated to the xDS server depending on their severity

messages.name: Status
messages.description: Status indicates whether a config resource (currently only [virtualservices](../introduction/concepts.md) and [upstreams](../introduction/concepts.md)) has been (in)validated by gloo

fields.name: state
fields.description: State is the enum indicating the state of the resource

fields.name: reason
fields.description: Reason is a description of the error for Rejected resources. If the resource is pending or accepted, this field will be empty

messages.name: Upstream
messages.description:
Upstream represents a destination for routing. Upstreams can be compared to
[clusters](https://www.envoyproxy.io/docs/envoy/latest/api-v1/cluster_manager/cluster.html?highlight=cluster) in Envoy terminology.
Upstreams can take a variety of types<!--(TODO)--> in gloo. Language extensions known as plugins<!--(TODO)--> allow the addition of new
types of upstreams. <!--See [upstream types](TODO) for a detailed description of available upstream types.-->

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the upstream. Names must be unique and follow the following syntax rules:
One or more lowercase rfc1035/rfc1123 labels separated by '.' with a maximum length of 253 characters.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type indicates the type of the upstream. Examples include static<!--(TODO)-->, kubernetes<!--(TODO)-->, and [aws](../plugins/aws.md)
Types are defined by the plugin<!--(TODO)--> associated with them.

fields.name: connection_timeout
fields.description:
Connection Timeout tells gloo to set a timeout for unresponsive connections created to this upstream.
If not provided by the user, it will set to a default value

fields.name: spec
fields.description:
Spec contains properties that are specific to the upstream type. The spec is always required, but
the expected content is specified by the [upstream plugin] for the given upstream type.
Most often the upstream spec will be a map<string, string>

fields.name: functions
fields.description:
Certain upstream types support (and may require) [functions](../introduction/concepts.md#Functions).
Functions allow function-level routing to be done. For example, the [AWS lambda](../plugins/aws.md) upstream type
Permits routing to AWS lambda function].
[routes](virtualservice.md#Route) on virtualservices can specify function destinations to route to specific functions.
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: service_info
fields.description:
Service Info contains information about the service running on the upstream
Service Info is optional, but is used by certain plugins (such as the gRPC plugin)
as well as discovery services to provide sophistocated routing features for well-known
types of services

fields.name: status
fields.description: Status indicates the validation status of the upstream resource. Status is read-only by clients, and set by gloo during validation

fields.name: metadata
fields.description: Metadata contains the resource metadata for the upstream

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type indicates the type of service running on the upstream.
Current options include `REST`, `gRPC`, and `NATS`

fields.name: properties
fields.description:
Properties contains properties that describe the service. The spec may be required
by the Upstream Plugin that handles the given Service Type
Most often the service properties will be a map<string, string>

fields.name: name
fields.description: Name of the function. Functions are referenced by name from routes and therefore must be unique within an upstream

fields.name: spec
fields.description: Spec for the function. Like [upstream specs](TODO), the content of function specs is specified by the [upstream plugin](TODO) for the upstream's type.

messages.name: VirtualService
messages.description:
Virtual Services represent a collection of routes for a set of domains.
Gloo's Virtual Services can be compared to
[virtual hosts](https://www.envoyproxy.io/docs/envoy/latest/api-v1/route_config/vService.html?highlight=virtual%20host) in Envoy terminology.
A virtual service can be used to define "apps"; a collection of APIs that belong to a particular domain.
The Virtual Service concept allows configuration of per-virtualservice SSL certificates

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the virtual service. Names must be unique and follow the following syntax rules:
One or more lowercase rfc1035/rfc1123 labels separated by '.' with a maximum length of 253 characters.

fields.name: domains
fields.description:
Domains represent the list of domains (host/authority header) that will match for all routes on this virtual service.
As in Envoy: wildcard hosts are supported in the form of *.foo.com or *-bar.foo.com.
If domains is empty, gloo will set the domain to "*", making that virtual service the "default" virtualservice.
The default virtualservice will be the fallback virtual service for all requests that do not match a domain on an existing virtual service.
Only one default virtual service can be defined (either with an empty domain list, or a domain list that includes "*")
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: routes
fields.description: Routes define the list of [routes](../) that live on this virtual service.
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: ssl_config
fields.description:
SSL Config is optional for the virtual service. If provided, the virtual service will listen on the envoy HTTPS listener port (default :8443)
If left empty, the virtual service will listen on the HTTP listener port (default :8080)

fields.name: disable_for_gateways
fields.description:
indicates whether or not this virtual service should be assigned to gateway roles automatically
TODO: eventually this flag will be deprecated; gateway roles will have to explicitly state the virtual services
they have access to.

fields.name: status
fields.description: Status indicates the validation status of the virtual service resource. Status is read-only by clients, and set by gloo during validation

fields.name: metadata
fields.description: Metadata contains the resource metadata for the virtual service

messages.name: Route
messages.description: Routes declare the entrypoints on virtual services and the upstreams or functions they route requests to

fields.name: request_matcher
fields.description:
request_matcher indicates this route should match requests according to the specification in the provided RequestMatcher
only one of request_matcher or event_matcher can be set

fields.name: event_matcher
fields.description:
eventt_matcher indicates this route should match requests according to the specification in the provided EventMatcher
only one of request_matcher or event_matcher can be set

fields.name: multiple_destinations
fields.description:
A route is only allowed to specify one of multiple_destinations or single_destination. Setting both will result in an error
Multiple Destinations is used when a user wants a route to balance requests between multiple destinations
Balancing is done by probability, where weights are specified for each destination
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: single_destination
fields.description: A single destination is specified when a route only routes to a single destination.

fields.name: prefix_rewrite
fields.description: PrefixRewrite can be specified to rewrite the matched path of the request path to a new prefix

fields.name: extensions
fields.description:
Extensions provides a way to extend the behavior of a route. In addition to the core route extensions<!--(TODO)-->,
gloo provides the means for route plugins<!--(TODO)--> to be added to gloo which add new types of route extensions.
<!--See the route extensions section for a more detailed explanation-->

messages.name: RequestMatcher
messages.description:
Request Matcher is a route matcher for traditional http requests
Request Matchers stand in juxtoposition to Event Matchers, which match "events" rather than HTTP Requests

fields.name: path_prefix
fields.description:
Prefix will match any request whose path begins with this prefix
Only one of path_prefix, path_regex, or path_exact can be set

fields.name: path_regex
fields.description:
Regex will match any path that matches this regex string
Only one of path_prefix, path_regex, or path_exact can be set

fields.name: path_exact
fields.description:
Exact will match only requests with exactly this path
Only one of path_prefix, path_regex, or path_exact can be set

fields.name: headers
fields.description:
Headers specify a list of request headers and their values the request must contain to match this route
If a value is not specified (empty string) for a header, all values will match so long as the header is present on the request
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: query_params
fields.description: Query params work the same way as headers, but for query string parameters
fields.label: repeated

fields.name: verbs
fields.description: HTTP Verb(s) to match on. If none specified, the matcher will match all verbs
fields.label: repeated

messages.name: EventMatcher
messages.description:
Event matcher is a special kind of matcher for CloudEvents
The CloudEvents API is described here: https://github.com/cloudevents/spec/blob/master/spec.md

fields.name: event_type
fields.description: Event Type indicates the event type or topic to match

messages.name: WeightedDestination
messages.description:
WeightedDestination attaches a weight to a destination
For use in routes with multiple destinations

fields.name: weight
fields.description:
Weight must be greater than zero
Routing to each destination will be balanced by the ratio of the destination's weight to the total weight on a route

messages.name: Destination
messages.description: Destination is a destination that requests can be routed to.

fields.name: function
fields.description:
function indicates requests sent to this destination will invoke a function
Only one of funtion or upstream should be set

fields.name: upstream
fields.description:
upstream indicates requests sent to this destination will be routed to an upstream
Only one of funtion or upstream should be set

messages.name: FunctionDestination
messages.description: FunctionDestination will route a request to a specific function defined for an upstream

fields.name: upstream_name
fields.description: Upstream Name is the name of the upstream the function belongs to

fields.name: function_name
fields.description: Function Name is the name of the function as defined on the upstream

messages.name: UpstreamDestination
messages.description: Upstream Destination routes a request to an upstream

fields.name: name
fields.description: Name of the upstream

messages.name: SSLConfig
messages.description: SSLConfig contains the options necessary to configure a virtualservice or listener to use TLS

fields.name: secret_ref
ssl_files
fields.description: SSLFiles reference paths to certificates which are local to the proxy

fields.name: sni_domains
fields.description: optional. the SNI domains that should be considered for TLS connections
fields.label: repeated

messages.name: SSLFiles
messages.description: SSLFiles reference paths to certificates which can be read by the proxy off of its local filesystem

fields.name: root_ca
fields.description: for client cert validation. optional

scalarValueTypes.notes: Uses variable-length encoding. Inefficient for encoding negative numbers  if your field is likely to have negative values, use sint32 instead.
Uses variable-length encoding. Inefficient for encoding negative numbers  if your field is likely to have negative values, use sint64 instead.
Uses variable-length encoding. Signed int value. These more efficiently encode negative numbers than regular int32s.
Uses variable-length encoding. Signed int value. These more efficiently encode negative numbers than regular int64s.
Always four bytes. More efficient than uint32 if values are often greater than 2^28.
Always eight bytes. More efficient than uint64 if values are often greater than 2^56.
A string must always contain UTF-8 encoded or 7-bit ASCII text.
May contain any arbitrary sequence of bytes.
